title: Calm Breathing (Diaphragmatic)
content: Find a comfortable seat. Breathe in slowly through your nose for about 4 seconds, let your belly expand, hold 1–2 seconds, then exhale slowly through your mouth for about 4 seconds. Repeat 5–8 cycles or until you feel steadier. This pattern helps down-regulate the nervous system.

title: Box/4-4-4 Breathing
content: Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold for 4. Repeat 6 times. Use when anxiety spikes to bring the body into a steady rhythm.

title: Why Breathing Helps
content: Slow, controlled breathing influences the vagus nerve and reduces sympathetic arousal (fight/flight). It changes blood CO2/O2 balance and signals safety to the brain, easing physical anxiety symptoms.

title: Mindful Breathing Short Practice
content: Set a 2–5 minute timer. Focus on the feeling of breath at the nostrils or belly. If thoughts come, label them 'thinking' and gently return to breath. Use daily to build present-moment skill.

title: Mindfulness Foundations
content: Mindfulness trains noticing present experience without judging. Over time it weakens habitual worry loops by shortening the time spent in future-oriented rumination.

title: Body Scan (5–10 minutes)
content: Lie or sit comfortably. Slowly bring attention from toes → head, noticing sensations. Breathe into areas of tension and imagine them releasing. Useful before sleep or after a stressful event.

title: Stress Response 101
content: Stress activates the sympathetic nervous system (adrenaline, faster heart rate, shallow breathing) to prepare for action. In safe modern contexts this response is often unnecessary; learning regulation reduces harmful effects.

title: Grounding 5-4-3-2-1
content: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, 1 thing you can taste. This sensory shift helps break panic loops.

title: Progressive Muscle Relaxation (Short)
content: Tense a muscle group for 5 seconds, then release for 10. Move through legs → torso → arms → neck → face. Notice contrast between tension and relaxation.

title: What Are Safety Behaviours?
content: Safety behaviours (checking, reassurance-seeking, avoidance) give short-term relief but prevent learning that feared outcomes are manageable. Reducing these supports lasting change.

title: Brief Cognitive Restructuring
content: Step 1: Identify automatic thought. Step 2: Find evidence for and against it. Step 3: Create a balanced alternative. Use when worry skews perception towards extremes.

title: Rumination vs Reflection
content: Rumination loops without problem-solving; reflection is intentional and goal-directed. The goal is to shift repetitive worry into brief, solution-focused reflection when useful.

title: Worry Time (Scheduled Worry)
content: Set a 15–20 minute worry slot daily. When worries arise outside it, jot them down and postpone. During worry time, evaluate which worries need action and which can be let go.

title: Self-Compassion Basics
content: Self-compassion involves treating yourself with the same kindness you’d offer a friend when you struggle. It reduces shame and increases emotional resilience.

title: Self-Compassion Break (Short)
content: Say silently: 'This is a moment of suffering. Suffering is part of life. May I be kind to myself in this moment.' Pause and take two steady breaths.

title: Behavioral Activation — Small Steps
content: When anxiety reduces activity, schedule small, achievable goals (15–30 minutes). Doing a little often rebuilds momentum and improves mood.

title: Cognitive Distortions Cheat-Sheet
content: Common distortions: all-or-nothing thinking, catastrophizing, mind-reading, discounting positives. Learning to spot them helps reframe unhelpful thinking.

title: Thought Record Template (Short)
content: Record: Situation → Automatic thought → Emotion (0–100) → Evidence for → Evidence against → Balanced thought → Outcome. Use once daily when stuck.

title: Personalization: Tone Matching
content: Match language to user preference (formal vs casual). Acknowledge user’s words, then offer choices. E.g., 'Do you want a quick grounding now, or a step-by-step breathing guide?'

title: Intensity Adaptation – Short vs Long Scripts
content: Provide micro-responses (1–2 lines) for high-intensity crisis steps (plus escalation), and longer psychoeducation for low-intensity check-ins. Adapt length to current user state.

title: Cultural Considerations in Support
content: Be aware of cultural beliefs about mental health. Offer options, avoid assumptions, and allow users to choose language and coping strategies aligned with their culture.

title: Age-Appropriate Language Guide
content: With younger users use simpler sentences, concrete examples, and short steps. With adults use fuller explanations and optional deeper exercises.

title: Micro-Validation Phrases
content: Examples: 'That sounds really hard' / 'I hear how worried you are' / 'It makes sense you'd feel this way.' Use early to build rapport.
source: Empathy scripts used in mental-health chat

title: Short Soothing Script (3 lines)
content: 'I’m sorry you’re feeling this. Let’s take one slow breath together. You’re not alone right now.' Keep it brief and actionable.

title: Relapse Normalization
content: Setbacks are common. Normalize them with: 'Progress isn’t linear — slips happen. What matters is noticing and returning to skills you know.'

title: Celebration / Progress Script
content: Prompt users to note small wins: 'What’s one small thing you did this week you’re proud of? Let’s celebrate that.' Encourages positive reinforcement.

title: How to Use RAG Content Safely
content: Keep psychoeducation short and cite sources. Use step-based instructions for techniques. For anything suggesting medical action, advise consulting a professional.
source: Best practice for RAG in health applications

title: Quick Distraction Options (3 choices)
content: Offer 3 brief activities: '1) Listen to a 2-min song, 2) Do 10 squats, 3) Name 5 things you see.' Short choices reduce decision friction in distress.

title: Why Small Steps Work
content: Small, repeated actions change habits by creating new learning. Practicing one short skill daily is more effective than many skills seldom used.

title: Guided 60-Second Reset
content: Prompt: 'Sit, take a slow breath in for 4, out for 6. Name one thing you can see, one thing you can feel. Repeat twice.' Use for quick de-escalation.

title: When To Suggest Professional Help
content: Recommend professional help if user reports suicidal ideation, self-harm intent, psychosis, or if symptoms severely impair daily life. Provide crisis resources and encourage contacting local emergency services.

title: Compassionate Self-Questioning
content: Prompt: 'If a friend told you this, what would you say to them? Now try saying that to yourself.' Helps shift harsh self-talk toward compassion.

title: When to Use Longer Scripts
content: Use longer psychoeducation when user indicates curiosity and low distress. In high distress keep replies short and focus on de-escalation.

title: Daily Check-In Template
content: Ask: 'How are you feeling today (1–10)? One word that describes why? One small thing you’ll do today for yourself?' This keeps users engaged and builds habit.

title: Universal Reassurance Bank
content: Short sample lines: 'You’re doing your best.' 'It’s okay to take things slowly.' 'I’m here to help you through this moment.' Use to personalize tone.
